issue.title: flaky `pytorch/vision` diffs

repository.name: mypy_primer
repository.description: Run mypy and pyright over millions of lines of code

issue.body:
Last couple of days I noticed a lot of unrelated mypy_primer diffs for an unused ignore at `pytorch/vision/torchvision/utils.py:270`. Sometimes it's a `+` (e.g. https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/28820), and sometimes it's a `-` (e.g. https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/28807). 

I'm not sure whether this is caused by some mypy_primer issue (e.g. caching-related), or if there's some non-determinism in mypy at play here. So I thought I'd try it here first, before I reflexively blame mypy again ðŸ˜œ.

body: One more example with random primer diffs on `xarray`, it only started appearing recently: https://github.com/python/mypy/pull/19102#issuecomment-2888495802

issue.title: Fix/attrs init overload
issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/19003

This PR fixes the issue by handling the case where the __init__ method can be an OverloadedFuncDef with CallableType items.

issue.title: Avoid false `unreachable`, `redundant-expr`, and `redundant-casts` warnings in loops more robustly and efficiently, and avoid multiple `revealed type` notes for the same line.
issue.body:
Fixes #18606 
Closes #18511
Improves #18991
Fixes #19170

This change is an improvement over 9685171.  Besides fixing the regressions reported in #18606 and #19170 and removing the duplicates reported in #18511, it should significantly reduce the performance regression reported in #18991.  At least running `Measure-command {python runtests.py self}` on my computer (with removed cache) is 10 % faster.

body: xarray might be a newer regression, since I can't repro with a few runs of `mypy_primer --new 'v1.15' --old 'v1.15' -k pydata/xarray --debug --output concise`. I'll try to bisect it later

Almost sure that xarray will bisect to #18976 (where it appeared for the
first time and was expected), but that's not the cause - xarray
indeterminism looks like the problem with noncommutative meet/join we are
already aware of. I wasn't able to repro it - any MRE I managed to think of
fails every time, not randomly.

On Fri, May 23, 2025, 22:50 Shantanu ***@***.***> wrote:

> *hauntsaninja* left a comment (python/mypy#19121)
> <https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/19121#issuecomment-2905781098>

> --new 'v1.15' --old 'v1.15' -k pydata/xarray --debug --output concise.
> I'll try to bisect it later

> .
> You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

Simple minimised version of torchvision:
```
printf '
def draw(
    colors1: list[str | tuple[int, int, int]] | str | tuple[int, int, int] | None,
    colors2: list[str | tuple[int, int, int]] | str | tuple[int, int, int] | None,
) -> None:
    for c1, c2 in zip(colors1, colors2):
        reveal_type(c1)
        reveal_type(c2)
' > test.py


first_output="$(mypy test.py)"
echo "$first_output"
echo "----------"
for run in {2..10}; do
  current_output="$(mypy test.py)"
  echo "$current_output"
  echo "----------"
  if [[ "$current_output" != "$first_output" ]]; then
    echo output mismatch
    exit 1
  fi
done
```

Also linking https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/16979 and https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/18125

issue.title: Fix nondeterministic type checking caused by nonassociativity of joins
issue.body:
I thought about doing this in `join_type_list`, but most callers look like they do have some deterministic order.

Fixes #19121 (torchvision case only, haven't looked at xarray)

Fixes #16979 (OP case only, bzoracler case fixed by #18402)

body:
The vision one will be fixed by #19147 

I think something similar will fix xarray. Both of these look like nonassociative issue (not a noncommutative issue!). I will do it in a follow up PR

issue.title: Fix nondeterministic type checking caused by nonassociative of None joins
issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/19121 (xarray case)

See #19147 for context 

The ordering of the union is still nondeterministic. We could solve this by change the solver to use `dict[Type, None` instead of `set[Type]` since dicts are ordered. But doing so could paper over further bad solving from nonassociativity or noncommutativity
